adjectives.description: pants (comparative more pants, superlative most pants)

examples: Your mobile is pants — why don’t you get one like mine?

entries.meaning: (chiefly Canada, US, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, India, Singapore, North West England) An outer garment that covers the body from the waist downwards, covering each leg separately, usually as far as the ankles; trousers. [from 19th c.]
examples: “But they cover the legs,” Joseph explained. “That is the only reason my people wear pants: to cover the legs in the winter, or when traveling through rough country, full of thorns. In warm weather, or in open country, pants are unnecessary, uncomfortable, and foolish.”

entries.meaning: (chiefly UK) An undergarment that covers the genitals and often the buttocks and the neighbouring parts of the body; underpants. [from 19th c.]
examples: I decided to pass up her underclothes, not from feelings of delicacy, but because I couldn't see myself putting her pants on and snapping her brassière.
The film was a load [or pile] of pants.

verbs.description: pants (third-person singular simple present pantses, present participle pantsing, simple past and past participle pantsed)

entries.meaning: To pull someone’s pants down; to forcibly remove someone’s pants.
examples: Keith Gerber has been pantsed twice already this summer by Lannie and Cling, and so his face is more resolved, the fear tempered by the fact that he understands these things to be inevitable.

entries.meaning: third-person singular simple present indicative of pant
